results.title: Shoalwater: up for grabs
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, Helen Stickley-Thompson and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: This film is about a group of people fighting for the preservation of Shoalwater Bay (Queensland). With its sweeping bays, untouched golden beaches, its jungle and rainforest, 200 metre high sand-dunes (purported to be the oldest in the world), Shoalwater Bay is home to a multitude of birds, plants and wildlife. But this is all under threat due to both the Federal and Queensland State Governments issuing exploratory sandmining leases to several Australian and Japanese mining companies - the justification being the potential creation of jobs. However, there are many who would dispute the actual number of jobs which will become available and who argue that this unique part of Queensland’s coastline must be preserved at all costs. Produced by Award-Winning Documentary filmmaker, David Bradbury and narrated by Peter Garrett (of Midnight Oil fame).

results.title: Shoah: second era
results.creator_credit: Claude Lanzmann and Les Films Aleph
results.brief_description: Director Claude Lanzmann’s ‘Shoah’ (the Hebrew word for destruction or annihilation), attempts to create in the present the reality of the Holocaust through the memories of its survivors, both victims and perpetrators. This remarkable documentary achieves this without a single use of archival or found footage, rather letting the horror of the Holocaust resonate through the myriad of stories and the faces of the survivors. Lanzmann and his documentary crew take their subjects through the now abandoned fields and buildings of their past torment, as they recount and talk the viewer through the unknowable and unthinkable. Images such as disused train tracks, overgrown with grass and leading nowhere take on a chilling and profound resonance as we are left to contemplate what happened there. (Awards: Winner of the 1985 New York Film Critics Circle Award and the 1985 National Society of Film Critics Awards-USA)

results.title: Shellshocked
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Jane Ramsey and Ramsey Films
results.brief_description: Four very different Australian veterans of the Vietnam war, all permanently affected by shellshock, return to Vietnam as part of the process of healing the trauma they suffered. This documentary follows the veterans as they travel together, flashing back to their individual war stories which are illustrated with unique home video footage. The high moment of the film occurs when they meet with veterans from the other side: ex Viet Cong guerrillas who, just like the Australian vets, are suffering from post-traumatic stress. A film about redemption that provides some startling insights into the nature of war.

results.title: Shirt factory
results.creator_credit: Hazel Swift and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A reaction, expressed in dance and mime, to a school visit to the local shirt factory; a protest at the monotony of piece work. Adapted from an original stage production for an end of term concert at Markfield Secondary School, North London.

results.title: Shirley MacLaine's inner workout (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Michael Wiese and Higher Self Seminars
results.brief_description: There is no escaping stress in our world, that’s why “Shirley MacLaine’s inner workout” is such a breakthrough. It’s a workout for mind, body and soul that’s every bit as important as daily exercise. It’s a comprehensive workout using meditation and relaxation techniques practiced for centuries in the Orient. Each meditation focuses on specific emotional areas such as creativity, control, love, sexuality, power, communication, judgement and more.

results.title: Christianity: the way of goodness and mercy
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Religions of the world”.
Christianity is a religion which has more followers than any other. Jesus Christ is the central figure of worship and his life, deeds and teachings had a profound effect on human history. Shot in various locations, the program discusses everything from the Sermon on the Mount to the Dead Sea Scrolls.

results.title: Orthodox and Roman Catholicism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Religions of the world”.
Orthodox and Roman Catholicism have their roots in the first century of the Common Era and have been intrinsically tied to the development of world history. Narrated by Ben Kingsley, this video compares the differences between the two religions, describing the practices, customs and traditions.

results.title: Religions of the world
results.brief_description: This series sets out to examine the characteristics of the five main world religions: Islam, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity and Hinduism. Each episode looks at the history and present day practices.

results.title: Shinto
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Religions of the world”.
Shinto, the indigenous religion of Japan, is one of the world’s oldest religious traditions and currently has around sixty-two million followers. It is rooted in mythology and folk rituals that have been passed down through the generations and although it has no congressional worship, founder, or written doctrine, it has at times served to unify Japan as a nation and to mobilise the country politically. Narrated by Ben Kingsley this video describes the social codes and daily life of its followers.

results.title: Judaism: the religion of a people
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Religions of the world”.
The religious practices and laws of Judaism have been handed down intact over many milleniums. This program looks at the foundations of Jewish teaching and laws as well as giving insight into the history of the Jewish people and their struggle to keep their identity and homeland.
